Chemical Safety and Emergency Response Policies

An outline of the duties and responsibilities required to be performed by all DAP associates when conducting business on behalf of DAP is discussed below. All DAP associates shall be made aware of their responsibilities under this program and given access to this policy, as required, in order to ensure a safe working environment for all our associates and the surrounding community. 

Policy Statement

It is the intent of DAP Inc. to provide each associate a safe and healthful work environment.  There is no job that we perform that is so important that it would jeopardize the health or well being of one of our associates or of our surrounding community.

This will be achieved through?

1. Providing the resources to develop and maintain an effective health and safety program

2. Consulting with associates on health and safety issues through the facilities respective safety committee's

3. Development of a comprehensive policy/procedure manual in support of this policy

Responsibilities

It is a basic responsibility of all DAP associates to make the health and safety of fellow human beings a part of their daily concern. This responsibility must be accepted by each one who conducts the affairs of DAP, no matter in what capacity he/she may function.

President, Vice Presidents, Directors, and Facility Management are responsible and accountable for:

1. Ensuring that activities are resourced to the extent necessary to ensure the health and safety of persons either performing or who are affected by those activities.

2. Implementing and requiring compliance with safety measures within their control in accordance with applicable rules and regulations as outlined in the DAP Inc. Health and Safety Manual.

3. Provide or arrange to provide safety and health related information, instruction, training and supervision to all persons under your control, including contractors and visitors to ensure that any risk is minimized.

4. Ass

istance in the formulation and review of specific safety rules for activities conducted within their area of control.
All employees of DAP Corporation are:

1. Responsible for following safe work practices consistent with the extent of their control or influence over working conditions and methods.

2. Required to cooperate with management in achieving a safe and healthy workplace.

3. Required to take reasonable care for their own health and safety and of anyone who may be affected by their actions.

4. Encouraged to actively participate and contribute to the continuous improvement of DAP's health and safety policies and procedures. 

Visitors and Contractors
Are required to comply with all reasonable instructions given while on DAP property.


The DAP Inc. Tipp City Facility and Regulated Substances Handled 

The Tipp City plant manufactures water and solvent (oil) based wood finishes, solvent based adhesives, latex based foam sealant, floor covering adhesives, and solvent based aerosol paint. The production process for some of these products requires the use of oil-based solvents. These solvents are stored and used throughout the site in large quantities.  

The plant is located on the west side of North Third Street in Tipp City, Ohio.  The 148,000-ft2 building is located on 42.9 acres across the street from the Miami River.  Some of the building's process water (i.e. non-contact cooling water) and surrounding roadways and parking areas storm water, flows into a grass and rock ditch system that surrounds these areas.  The ditch water on the north side of the building flows into the Miami river located on the east side of North Third Street (approximately 500 feet from the property's fenceline). Control Measures
For ruptured tank, shut off all electric motors, pilot lights, heaters, valves from tank, any trucks or cars in the area.
Remove personnel in general area
Put up road block keeping vehicles out of area
Use water fog to evaporate or ventilate
Seal off flow of any material through the damaged vessel     

Prevention Measures
Sprinkler deluge system completely surrounds tanks, triggered by heat
Check tanks and pipes for any possible leaks before unloading
Make sure hoses at unloading station properly sealed before starting unloading process.  
Pressure relief valves on the tanks
Manual and automatic shutoffs in case of emergency
Grounding and bonding systems in place
Excess flow valves are in place
Follow SOP for tank car unloading to insure that:
1) Tanks are not to be filled above 80% due to expansion
2) Make sure all valves are closed after unloading
 Check pipes for any possible leaks
Mechanical Integrity
Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

The process addressed in the RMP is also covered under the OSHA process safety management program (29CFR 1910.119). Because of this, DAP, Tipp City is required to comply with a variety of items including, but not limited to, the following:

* Conducting Process Hazard Analysis 

* Training and competency testing for associates and contractors who work on the process

* Establishment of a Hot Work Program

* Ensuring Full Employee Participation in the PSM program

* Writing SOP's

* Pre-Start Up Safety Reviews before starting up a covered process

* Ensuring m

echanical integrity for all parts on the covered process, etc.

In addition to complying with the OSHA PSM program, DAP, Tipp City has also ensured the process is safe through the use of several technology based systems associated with the covered process including but not limited to, the following:

* Interlocks on the propellant pumps in case a release occurs.

* E-stop buttons that shut down all pumps coming from the tanks.

* Pressure relief valves are installed on all piping runs and on the tank valves.

* Excess flow valves are installed on the tanks to avoid overpressure during filling. 

* Supervised pressure relief valves are installed in the gashouses

* Deluge system is present

* A water cannon is present

* All brush and vegetation has been cleared from around the tanks, etc.

The Five Year Accident History

Over the course of the preceding five years, DAP, Tipp City, has had no accident involving our covered process that resulted in deaths, injuries, property damage onsite or known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage or environmental damage, evacuations or sheltering in place. 

Emergency Response Program

Due to the potential dangers to employee trained emergency responders, DAP, Tipp City does not have a trained Spill Response Team to respond to emergencies involving the release of hazardous substances on site.  The plant has agreements in place with a local emergency contractor to respond to all spills that are not considered incidental. 

Coordination with Outside Agencies

Representatives from the Tipp City fire, police and local emergency planning commission (LEPC) have toured the Tipp City facility in the past.  These organizations were given a copy of relevant plans, maps, etc., in 2003. When adjustments are made to the plan for whatever reason, modified copies are sent to the appropriate agencies. It is DAP's intention to have all parties visit and walkthrough the plant every time the plan must be re-certified in order to familiarize the

mselves with the latest modifications. Upper Valley Medical Center (UVMC) employees (Program director and Physician) were given a tour of the plant as well. They will also receive a copy of this plan whenever updated. 

Copies of the Emergency Spill Response Procedures are located in designated areas throughout the plant.  These procedures include the requirements for reporting the incident, alerting all affected parties and implementing the necessary countermeasures, and assigning to certain site personnel the responsibility for insuring that these requirements are met.  Each procedure is reviewed and revised as necessary to keep pace with changing conditions at the site.  Material Safety Data Sheets, for the chemicals or substances used at the plant, are located outside the Production Supervisor's office, in the QA/QC lab and in the ESH Manager's office.  

GENERAL SPILL RESPONSE PROCEDURES

In the event of a spill the following actions will be taken:

If it is a minor spill:

* less than two (2) gallons of materials with any HMIS rating of 3 or higher,  or 

* less than five (5) gallons of any other material, 

* and you are familiar with the substance (its hazards and handling procedures) perform steps a) - i). 

A) Don the appropriate protective equipment

b) Notify anyone in the area that there has been a spill and ask them to avoid the immediate area.  Tape off the area.

C) Contain the spill using one of the following

* Absorbent

* Pillows/socks/staydry

d) Notify your supervisor of the incident

e) Place the soiled absorbent/clean up materials in a sealable container.

F) Close and label the container as appropriate (Hazardous/Non Hazardous)

g) Remove container to appropriate storage area (Hazardous/Non Hazardous)

h) Document incident on "Spill Report Form"

If it is a major spill:

* more than two (2) gallons of materials with any HMIS rating of 3 or higher, or 

* more than five (5) gallons of any other material 

* and/or you are not familiar with th

e substance perform steps 3-5.

1. Notify your supervisor immediately and follow his/her instructions.

2. Supervisor will asses the situation and take the following actions:

a) Determine whether an evacuation is necessary.  If evacuation is necessary the Supervisor will activate the "Plant Emergency Evacuation Procedure".  If not, restrict access to affected area.

B) Notify the Emergency Response Coordinator or Alternate.  Turn the situation over to the Coordinator and follow his/her instructions.

3. Emergency Response Coordinator will asses the situation and take the following actions:

a) Determine whether outside help is needed.  If so, call the local emergency response contractor number and relay the following information:

* The type of emergency

* The location or zone of the plant where the emergency is located

* If there is a hazard that could extend outside of the plant boundary

* If a plant employee will meet the responding vehicle and where.

B) Activate the Emergency Spill Response Procedure.

PERSONNEL RESPONSIBILITIES

Section 3745-65-55 of the Ohio Administrative Code (OAC) and 40 CFR 112.7(e)(10)(ii) requires the designation of specific person(s) to coordinate and/or be responsible for emergency response activities.  Tipp City has designated a Plant Emergency Coordinator and Alternate and a Spill Response Prevention Plan Administrator. Responsibilities are reviewed with the individual when the initial assignment is made and during annual and monthly emergency training.  

The Primary Emergency Coordinator or the Alternate will be either on site or on call (i.e., available to respond to an emergency by reaching the facility within a short period of time) at all times in case of an emergency.  

SPILL CLEANUP MATERIAL
In the event of a spill, the physical and mechanical cleanup will be done with such materials and equipment as absorbent pillows/pigs/staydry, mops, shovels, brooms, pumps, forklift and other tools as appropriate.

ve Equipment (PPE) and Spill Response Equipment are located throughout the plant and in each zone. Incidental spill kits which include sorbent pillows, gloves, etc. are located throughout the facility. Larger cabinets containing squeegees, brooms and absorbent materials have been placed near the floor covering area (Zone 4) and next to the wood finishes (Zone 2) lines. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Ways to make any process safer within DAP Inc, Tipp City is always a top priority. In regards to the covered process there has been a capitol appropriations request submitted and approved to install an IR LEL system at the location of the tanks. The LEL system will be interlocked with our aerosol gashouses to automatically shut all gas sources off upon detecting a 10% LEL condition. In addition to shutting off flow, the LEL condition will also call for evacuation of the facility.
